subject: Re: [junit] Private method throws an exception
msgSnippet: Mitch, You ve noticed quite a discussion by proxy.  I m interested in _your_ position.  Without knowing more about your domain, I can guess that depency
messageBody:
Mitch,

You've noticed quite a discussion by proxy. I'm interested in _your_
position. Without knowing more about your domain, I can guess that
depency injection might be a better option than making the method
protected, but probably for reasons other than simplicity of the
resulting code or interface. What are these reasons in your situtation?

David Saff

Mitch Christensen wrote:

> In my case, I know exactly what the problem is. The private method
> relies on external resources that are not available during unit
> testing (i.e. Torque/DBMS).
>
>
>
> My question was not how to find an unknown failure, but how to
> eliminate a known failure caused by an external dependency buried
> inside a private method.
>
>
>
> For public/protected method dependencies, I extend the class under
> test and override and simplify those methods. Unfortunately, this
> doesnâ€™t work for private methods.
>
>
>
> I think the answer is to refactor the private method to support some
> form of dependency injection so I can insert mock objects that
> eliminate the exception.
>
>
>
> My question was whether they may be a better/more efficient approach?
>
>
>
> Thanks again for your help.
>
> -Mitch
>
>
>
> _____
>
> From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf
> Of Elliotte Harold
> Sent: Monday, October 31, 2005 5:11 PM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: Re: [junit] Private method throws an exception
>
>
>
> J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
>
> > If you have a failing test, but you aren't sure why it fails, and you
> > suspect the problem is in a private method, what do you generally do?
>
> If I have a failing test that fails because an exception is thrown out
> of a private method, I debug it. First off I eyeball the code both in
> the private method and the public method being tested. Most of the time
> the reason for the failure is obvious. If it's not, I'll generally set a
> breakpoint or two and step through the code in the debugger and watch
> what actually happens. This is a lot more productive than guessing at
> what the problem might be. If I could guess right, then I wouldn't need
> to step through it.
>
> It used to be common in quality code to do a code review by stepping
> through the entire program in a debugger. This tended to reveal a lot of
> surprises about how the code was really working. This technique has
> fallen out of favor as applications grew larger. It's really impractical
> today. However, when something is going wrong in a known piece of code
> nothing beats single stepping through it in a debugger. This almost
> always points me to the exact statement where what I think the code is
> doing diverges from what the code is actually doing.
>
> This requires that the bug is consistently reproducible and I have a
> test that reproduces it. However, once I've got that I'm good to go.
> Writing hypothetical tests for what I think the bug might be only works
> if the bug is so obvious that I can eyeball it in the first place. The
> tricky bugs are the ones where everything looks like it should work and
> I can't see why it doesn't. That's when I need to isolate the problem
> more closely than a test method can. I need to find out which statement
> is failing, not which method is failing. I already know the answer to
> the latter question.
>
> If the bug proves to be deep inside another piece of code, then I might
> later add a second test that aims more closely at the bug. However,
> that's only done after I've identified the bug, and often I don't even
> bother to do that. After all, there's already at least one test for the
> issue.
>
> --
